questions.prompt: How many weeks does the orchestral classical music event known as ‘the Proms’ last for?
questions.explanation: The Proms is an eight-week summer season of orchestral classical music that takes place in various venues, including the Royal Albert Hall in London.

questions.prompt: When did King Charles III start reining?
questions.explanation: The King has reigned since his mother’s death in September 2022.

questions.prompt: What did the Chartists campaign for?
options: The right to vote for women over 30 years old
The right to vote for the working classes and other people without property
The right to vote for women and men over 30 years old
The right to vote for every citizen
questions.explanation: The Chartists, demanded the vote for the working classes and other people without property.

questions.prompt: What is the name of the land formation consisting of columns made of volcanic lava located on the north-east coast of Northern Ireland?
questions.explanation: Located on the north-east coast of Northern Ireland, the Giant’s Causeway is a land formation of columns made from volcanic lava.

questions.prompt: Members of the public are not allowed in Youth Courts, and the name or photographs of the accused young person cannot be published in newspapers or used by the media:
questions.explanation: This statement is true.

questions.prompt: A set of principles by which a country is governed and which includes all of the institutions that are responsible for running the country and how their power is kept in check is the definition for:
questions.explanation: A constitution is a set of principles by which a country is governed. It includes all of the institutions that are responsible for running the country and how their power is kept in check.

questions.prompt: When did Emmeline Pankhurst die?
questions.explanation: Emmeline Pankhurst died in 1928. Shortly before Emmeline’s death, women were given the right to vote at the age of 21, the same as men.

questions.prompt: What TWO houses were confronted during the Wars of the Roses?
questions.explanation: The Wars of the Roses were fought between the supporters of two families: the House of Lancaster and the House of York.

questions.prompt: What is the National Anthem of the UK?
questions.explanation: The National Anthem of the UK is ‘God Save the King’.

questions.prompt: Who was the first woman to become Prime Minister in the UK?
questions.explanation: Margaret Thatcher, Britain’s first woman Prime Minister, led the Conservative government from 1979 to 1990.

questions.prompt: When did the Brexit referendum take place?
questions.explanation: The referendum on the UK’s membership of the European Union or Brexit referendum was held on 23 June 2016.

questions.prompt: Which one of the following gardens is located in Northern Ireland?
questions.explanation: Mount Stewart is located in Northern Ireland, Bodnant Garden in Wales and Sissinghurst and Hidcote in England.

questions.prompt: When is the Mercury Music Prize awarded?
questions.explanation: The Mercury Music Prize is awarded each September for the best album from the UK and Ireland.

questions.prompt: Which of the following statements is true?
options: To apply to become a permanent resident or citizen of the UK, you will need to have a university degree
To apply to become a permanent resident or citizen of the UK, you will need to have a good understanding of life in the UK
To apply to become a permanent resident or citizen of the UK, you will need to have British relatives
To apply to become a permanent resident or citizen of the UK, you will need to have knowledge of the British laws
questions.explanation: To apply to become a permanent resident or citizen of the UK, you will need to have a good understanding of life in the UK and be able to speak and read English.

questions.prompt: Who invented the cash-dispensing ATM (automatic teller machine) or ‘cashpoint’?
questions.explanation: In the 1960s, James Goodfellow (1937-) invented the cash-dispensing ATM (automatic teller machine) or ‘cashpoint’. The first of these was put into use by Barclays Bank in Enfield, north London in 1967.

questions.prompt: What is the name of the only ‘Grand Slam’ tennis event played on grass?
questions.explanation: The Wimbledon Championships is the oldest tennis tournament in the world and the only ‘Grand Slam’ event played on grass.

questions.prompt: What is the meaning of the term ‘Habeas corpus’?
options: You must present the person in court
questions.explanation: Habeas corpus is Latin for ‘you must present the person in court’. The Habeas Corpus Act guaranteed that no one could be held prisoner unlawfully. Every prisoner has a right to a court hearing.

questions.prompt: What name is given to the candelabrum lit during the eight-day holiday of Hanukkah?
questions.explanation: Hanukkah is in November or December and is celebrated for eight days. On each day of the festival a candle is lit on a stand of eight candles (called a menorah) to remember the story of the festival, where oil that should have lasted only a day did so for eight.

questions.prompt: Which of the following statements is TRUE?
options: It is against the law to walk your dog on the beach
It is against the law to treat a pet cruelly or to neglect it
It is against the law to take pets into public places
It is against the law to feed your pet in public places
questions.explanation: It is against the law to treat a pet cruelly or to neglect it.

questions.prompt: Which German princess got married with Henry VIII?
questions.explanation: Anne of Cleves was a German princess who married Henry VIII for political reasons.

questions.prompt: In which of the following matters can the Scottish Parliament legislate (choose FIVE options)?
questions.explanation: The Scottish Parliament can legislate on: civil and criminal law, health, education, planning and additional tax-raising powers.

questions.prompt: Drinking in public can be a criminal offence and you can be fined or arrested for it:
questions.explanation: Drinking in public: some places have alcohol-free zones where you cannot drink in public. The police can also confiscate alcohol or move young people on from public places. You can be fined or arrested.

questions.prompt: What was the most spoken language during the Iron Age?
questions.explanation: The language spoken during the Iron Age was part of the Celtic language family.

questions.prompt: What charity works for the preservation of important buildings, coastline and countryside in the UK?
questions.explanation: The National Trust works for the preservation of important buildings, coastline and countryside in the UK.
